Available online 25 July 2023 Review Review of covalent organic frameworks for single-site photocatalysis and electrocatalysis Qing Niu Linhua Mi Wei Chen Qiujun Li Shenghong Zhong * Yan Yu * Liuyi Li * Key Laboratory of Eco-materials Advanced Technology, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350108, Fujian, China Key Laboratory of Eco-materials Advanced Technology College of Materials Science and Engineering Fuzhou University Fuzhou Fujian 350108 China Key Laboratory of Eco-materials Advanced Technology, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350108, Fujian, China * Corresponding author. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) represent a burgeoning category of highly tunable crystalline porous materials, which have garnered significant attention as promising platforms for designing novel photo- and electrocatalysts. Single-site catalysis holds paramount importance in revealing the catalytic reaction mechanism and enhancing catalytic performance because of the maximum utilization of metal atoms and presence of a definite active center. Given the distinct advantages of single-site catalysts, such as single metal ions, single atoms, single active sites, and metal clusters, and COFs materials, there is a current surge of interest in using COFs materials as support materials to anchor highly dispersed single-sites. Consequently, the design and preparation of COF-based single-site catalysts have emerged as a prominent research topic in the fields of photo- and electrocatalysis, to address the pressing environmental and energy issues. This review provides an overview of the development of COF-based single-site photo- and electrocatalysts. Advanced applications of COF-based single-site photo- and electrocatalysts are comprehensively summarized and reviewed. Additionally, the review addresses the challenges faced by COF-based single-site photo- and electrocatalysts and discusses their future development trends. We aim to provide new insights into the application of COF-based single-site materials in photo- and electrocatalysis and further promote the development of catalytic science. Graphical Abstract Advances in COF-based single-site photo- and electrocatalysts were thoroughly reviewed and highlighted. This review focuses on understanding the correlation between the activity and structure. The future development challenges and trends are also discussed. Keywords Covalent organic framework Single-site catalysis Photocatalysis Electrocatalysis 1 Introduction Expeditious industrialization has led to significant energy and environmental challenges, which have considerably influenced the sustainable development of society. To address these challenges, the exploration and utilization of green, clean, and sustainable energy sources as replacements to traditional fossil fuels have gained considerable attention [1–3]. Photo- and electrocatalysis driven by solar and electrical energies, respectively, have emerged as highly relevant and extensively researched areas owing to the convenience of using light and electricity [4–8]. The development and preparation of efficient photocatalysts are crucial for realizing the above energy conversion. Valuable photocatalysts and electrocatalysts generally possess abundant reactive sites and tunable properties [9–11]. However, most catalysts reported in the literature do not fully meet the above prerequisite [12–15]. Specifically, the poor tunability of the structure and low utilization efficiency of the metal atoms greatly limit their practical applications. In 2011, Zhang et al. [16] synthesized a highly active and stable Pt1/FeO x catalyst for CO oxidation and proposed the concept of single-atomic-site catalyst. Since then, single-metal atom catalysts have attracted significant attention in the field of heterogeneous catalysis owing to the exceptional utilization efficiency of atoms and the presence of highly dispersed active atomic components [17–21]. Isolated metal atoms are effectively immobilized by bonding with supports or other metals. Their catalytic activity is significantly influenced by the surrounding coordination environment, which form single active sites. These single active sites (designated as a single-site) consists of not only isolated metals, such as single metal atoms, metal clusters, metal ions, and metal complexes but also include the adjacent partial components of the supporters. The unique features of single-site catalysts offer many advantages in heterogeneous photocatalysis and electrocatalysis [22–28]. However, their high mobility and aggregation hinder practical catalytic application [29–32]. Therefore, it is essential to identify suitable supports for the construction of single-site heterogeneous photocatalysts and electrocatalysts. To date, many supports have been constructed and reported, including metal oxides (TiO2, Fe2O3, and Al2O3), metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), and zeolites [33–40]. Nevertheless, the reported supports for preparing single-site catalysts always face some drawbacks, such as limited structural tunability, low surface area, insufficient active sites, and structural simplicity, which hamper their catalytic applications. Therefore, identifying suitable supports with strong metal-support interactions, designable and tailorable structures, and permanent porosity for anchoring single metal atoms is vital but challenging. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are an emerging class of crystalline organic polymers connected with organic building blocks by covalent bonds, to form two-dimensional (2D) or three-dimensional (3D) networks. Since the pioneering work of Yaghi et al. [41] in 2015, who reported the first COFs employing boroxine linkages, COFs have gained widespread attention because of their unique features, including well-ordered conjugated structures, tunable pores, modular synthesis, and high surface areas [41,42]. Compared with inorganic materials, COFs are structurally tunable and pre-designable, making them highly competitive as catalysts and platforms [43–45]. Moreover, COFs have large surface areas and open pores that can be used as scaffolds to confine and stabilize single-sites for forming COF-based single-site catalysts, exhibiting promising potential in the photo- and electrocatalysis fields [46–49]. The incorporation of a single-site may, in turn, impact the pore structures of COFs, which are also critical for reactant adsorption and conversion [50–52]. The confinement effect of the COF pore structure can affect the selectivity for the catalytic products. Most COFs are thermally and chemically stable under typical catalytic conditions. In general, imine-based COFs are stable in neutral aqueous solutions. Some hydrogen bonding-locked and sp 2 carbon-conjugated COFs were robust under acidic and basic conditions. In addition, COF-based single-site catalysts also exhibit remarkable advantages. (1) The highly crystalline and ordered structures of COFs contribute to the exploration of the relationship between structure and performance [45,53]. (2) The regulable and open pore structure of COFs can contain different host-guest molecules to improve the catalytic performance [43,54]. (3) The well-defined microstructures of the active sites of COF-based single-site catalysts can promote the activation of reactants and reveal the reaction mechanism [55,56]. (4) The structural diversity of COFs enables widespread application of COF-based single-site catalysts [44,57]. Therefore, superior photocatalytic and electrocatalytic performances are expected for COF-based single-site catalysts. Over the past few decades, significant progress has been made in photocatalysis and electrocatalysis using COF-based single-site catalysts (Fig. 1 ), suggesting that they are becoming a popular research field. Previous reviews on COFs have mainly focused on their structural design, synthesis, and potential for diverse applications [43,46,57–59]. Singh et al. [44] focused on COF-based single-metal-atom catalysts and summarized their advanced applications. The growing body of research on COF-based single-site catalysts in photo- and electrocatalysis has not yet been comprehensively reviewed and summarized. Therefore, there is a pressing need to conduct a systematic review of COF-based single-site photo- and electrocatalysts to summarize the recent advancements in understanding catalytic mechanisms and design principles. Additionally, such a review should address the challenges faced and provide perspectives for future developments. Herein, we summarize the structural traits, development, and perspectives of COF-based single-site photo- and electrocatalysts. By combining in-situ studies and theoretical calculations, we conducted a detailed analysis of the possible catalytic mechanism and proposed a modification strategy for photocatalysis. Advanced applications of COF-based single-site catalysts in photo- and electrocatalytic hydrogen evolution, CO2 reduction, pollutant degradation, N2 fixation, and other related areas are systematically outlined. The corresponding guidance images for this review are shown in Fig. 2 . Finally, the future challenges and perspectives of COF-based single-site catalysts for photo- and electrocatalysis are presented. We expect this review to deepen researchers’ understanding of COFs for photo- and electrocatalysis and help them design more efficient catalysts for energy conversion. 2 Structural basis of COFs for single-site photocatalysis and electrocatalysis In recent years, COF-based photocatalysts have attracted increasing attention owing to their uniform structural features. The photocatalytic mechanism of COF-based single-site photocatalyts involves key processes, such as light harvesting, charge generation and transport, and surface catalysis, which are similar to those of inorganic semiconductors [45,60]. For high solar conversion efficiency, COFs should primarily have the following attributes: (1) High crystalline conjugated structures that respond to visible light, which accounts for 45% of the solar spectrum [61]. (2) Electron donor-acceptor building units that facilitate the separation of the photoinduced charge carriers. The presence of a dipole moment originating from the adjacent units aids in the separation and transport of excitons [62,63]. (3) Coordination sites on the pore walls of COFs that enable the formation of single-sites with immobilized metal species, which serve as catalytically active sites [64]. The coordination bond also contributes to electron transfer. The construction of COFs for photocatalysts involves enhancing light adsorption, inhibiting the recombination of photoinduced charges, and improving the surface reaction kinetics. Owing to the advantages of COFs such as their adjustable and well-defined structures, open and permanent porosity, enriched heteroatoms, and easy modification and functionalization [44,65–68], COF-based single-site photocatalysts can be synthesized through coordination effects or host-guest interactions. As shown in Fig. 3 , upon light illumination, the photogenerated electrons and/or holes delocalize within the COF. The tunable structure can optimize light absorption and modulate the excited electron distribution. Hot electrons in COFs can be transported to a single site via covalent or hydrogen bonds to reduce the adsorbed reactants. Permanent pores can significantly improve the mass transfer and accessibility at a single-site [69]. The holes in COF react with electron donors such as sacrificial agents and/or H2O [55]. For electrochemical reactions, catalysts are typically utilized to minimize the overpotential and improve the energy conversion efficiency. Considering hydrogen-oxygen fuel cells as an example [70], a hydrogen molecule first splits into protons and electrons on the anode. Electrons then migrate from the anode to the cathode, where the O2 reduction reactions (ORRs) occur (Fig. 4(a) ). However, the ORR rate, which depends on the employed catalysts, determines the overall performance of fuel cells. Noble metals and their oxides, such as Pt for hydrogen evolution reactions (HERs) and RuO2 for OERs, are among the most active electrocatalysts (Fig. 4(b)). However, their high cost and scarcity restrict large-scale use. Ideally, the electrocatalysts should be highly active, cost-effective, and durable under harsh conditions. In particular, owing to their tunable pore structure and modifiable internal chemical environment, COFs display the following remarkable merits: (1) complex secondary organic structures, which are advantageous for their structural design; (2) strong covalent bonds, leading to excellent thermal/chemical stability; and (3) large surface area and adjustable pore size, resulting in outstanding adsorption properties [71]. COFs meet all the prerequisites of ideal electrocatalysts, making them promising materials for electrocatalysis [72]. COFs exhibit outstanding structural merits, including tunable energy-band structures, abundant and controllable active sites, and high porosity, for achieving single-site photocatalysis and electrocatalysis. The main structural advantage of COFs for single-site photocatalysis and electrocatalysis is their designable and tailorable structures. A structure capable of constructing redox sites on COFs is a prerequisite for achieving single-site redox catalysis. Moreover, charge transfer during catalysis can be achieved using 2D COFs. A large number of heteroatoms are required for the formation of a single site. Consequently, the integration of building blocks with heteroatoms in 2D COFs is crucial for designing COF-based single-site photo- and electrocatalysts. Additionally, the disadvantages of COF-based single-site catalysts must be addressed. Specifically, COFs are typically more sensitive to water than other inorganic semiconductors; therefore, attention should be paid to the effect of hydrolysis on the structural stability of aqueous systems. Robust stability can be obtained by intramolecular hydrogen bonding or by using sp 2 carbon-conjugated linkages [73–75]. Furthermore, the hydrophobicity derived from intrinsic aromatic structures should be considered. However, this hydrophobicity can be enhanced by adding hydrophilic groups to the frameworks [76]. For photocatalysis, significant attention must be directed towards the light stability of COFs during the photocatalytic process. Most COFs exhibit poor conductivities, which limit their electrocatalytic applications. The conductivity can be improved using redox units or by fabricating a single COF layer [77,78]. Moreover, until now, the most widely employed COF in catalysis have been powder crystals. However, the scalable preparation and application of COF single crystals still faces great challenges. Overcoming these challenges is significant for the accurate determination of catalytic active sites and regulation of the microenvironment. The challenges and shortcomings faced in photo- and electrocatalysis can be overcome via a molecular-level bottom-up structural control of COFs, by leveraging the structural tunability inherent to COFs. 3 Synthesis of COF-based single-site catalysts Based on the seminal viewpoint of strong atomic chemical interactions first proposed by Lewis [79] in 1916, covalent organic chemistry rapidly progressed from discrete chemistry to COFs, which was first demonstrated by Yaghi et al. [41] in 2005. COFs are constructed by integrating organic units via covalent bonds. In 2017, Yaghi et al. [80] provided a comprehensive overview encompassing the theoretical foundation, reticular synthesis, and significant synthesis advancements in COFs. They indicated that organic chemistry provides an extensive library of molecules for constructing COFs. Therefore, the synthesis of COFs the assembly of predetermined molecular building blocks into a framework via reticular chemistry. Over the past several decades, various types of organic reactions, including reversible and irreversible reactions, have been explored and employed to synthesize COFs with different organic units. These organic units enable COFs to exhibit unique characteristics, such as structural diversity, periodic structures, and low densities, and show impressive potential for application in photo- and electrocatalytic fields. 3.1 Synthetic methods of COFs for photo- and electrocatalysis Typical COFs with distinct linkages, including hydrazone, imine, 1,4-dioxin, triazine, azine, and vinyl linkages, have been successfully constructed for photo- and electrocatalytic applications using various synthetic protocols [81]. The diversity of linkages not only endows structural diversity and specific functionalities to COFs but also significantly influences their chemical stability and conductivity. Therefore, it is crucial to fabricate COF-based photo- and electrocatalysts through rational design of COF linkages. Typical synthetic reactions for COFs are shown in Fig. 5 . Among them, imine-linked COFs have attracted considerable research interest in photo- and electrocatalysis because of the broad scope of their monomers (amines and aldehydes) [59,72,74]. In addition, hydrazone-linked COFs have gained extensive attention for photocatalysis because of their high stability in water [59]. The intrinsic differences between the imine and hydrazone groups in COF can influence their catalytic activities [82]. In addition, other functional linkages for COFs fabrication have also been widely employed in photo- and electrocatalysis. The stability of these functional linkages can be adjusted and rendered acceptable via various strategies, such as the incorporation of methoxy into aldehydes, construction of enol-keto tautomerization, and post synthetic modification methods [74,83–87]. Under certain reaction conditions, the reversible linkages can be corrected and rearranged by cleavage and recombination for establishing a predetermined crystalline COF structure rather than an amorphous state. Methods for the synthesis of COFs with pre-designable structures and functional applications, especially in the photo- and electrocatalytic fields, have also been explored [58,88]. These methods include solvothermal, ionothermal, microwave, mechanochemical, and sonochemical methods (Fig. 6 ). The synthesis of COF-based single-site catalysts usually follows a facile approach involving in-situ photo deposition, post-impregnation, and directed assembly. Herein, we summarize the commonly used synthetic methods for COF-based single-site catalysts. Most COFs are synthesized via polycondensation reactions using a solvothermal method. Schiff base condensation reaction is a commonly employed reaction, in which the solubility and reactivity of organic monomers significantly affect the crystallinity of COFs. The solvent, reaction temperature, solvent, and concentration were the main reaction parameters. Typically, solvothermal reactions are conducted in a Pyrex tube. The tube was subjected to freeze-pump-thaw cycles, sealed, and then heated at a reasonable temperature for a certain time. Typical imine-, azine-, and hydrazone-linked COFs for photo- and electrocatalytic applications have been prepared using this method. For example, two COFs, namely TTA-TTB and TAPB-TTB, were prepared by the solvothermal method. These COFs are regarded as promising semiconductor material for H2 evolution under visible light, without any additives [89]. Compared to conventional solvothermal synthesis with a long reaction time, microwave synthesis often requires a short reaction time, such as the synthesis of boronated ester-linked COF-5 [90] and imine-linked TpPa-COF [91]. This method is conducted in a microwave tube, in which the monomers and solvent are mixed and heated at a certain temperature (100 or 110 °C) while being stirred for 60 min under a nitrogen or vacuum environment. It can be performed in open systems and under mild conditions without requiring the freezing-pump-thaw or flame-sealing processes, which are different from the solvothermal method. Some crystalline COFs have been prepared using the microwave method (eg., copper phthalocyanine- and azine-based COFs) [92–94], which are promising for photocatalytic applications. Ionothermal synthesis methods are primarily used to prepare triazine-based COFs, also known as CTFs. This reaction was performed in a Pyrex ampule, to which a predetermined monomer and ZnCl2 were added and sealed after evacuating air from the ampule. After heating at 400 °C or a higher temperature for a certain time, the solid in the ampule is collected, washed, and dried to get CTFs [95,96]. During the ionothermal synthesis process, molten ZnCl2 can be regarded as good solvents and catalysts for trimerization reactions, and these reaction can be considered reversible at high temperatures. Owing to their ultra stable triazine rings and nitrogen-rich structure, CTFs are increasingly used as excellent photocatalysts and electrocatalysts. Compared to solvothermal synthesis, the use of ionic liquids to synthesize COFs is quick, simple, and cost-effective [97]. The mechanochemical synthesis method requires only a simple mortar and pestle to grind different monomers together to obtain COFs. The reaction conditions were superior to those of both the solvothermal and microwave methods without the need for a specific Pyrex tube or an inert reaction system. Compared to the solvothermal method, this method is limited to some COFs, and these COFs usually have low crystallinity and porosity. Therefore, Banerjee et al. [98] reported a liquid-assisted grinding method to prepare imine-linked COFs to improve the crystallinity. In this method the reaction homogeneity and crystallinity of the COFs were greatly enhanced, and this contributed to their superior photocatalytic performance. Recently, sonochemistry method was explored and reported by Cooper et al. [99] to rapidly prepare (< 60 min) imine-linked COFs for photocatalytic hydrogen evolution. This method, offering notable advantages in terms of speed, simplicity, and versatility, while effectively circumventing the disadvantages of the solvothermal method, was performed in aqueous acetic acid. 3.2 Design principles of COF-based single-site catalysts Depending on the structural designability of the COFs, COF-based single-site catalysts can be synthesized by precisely regulating their components, including the building blocks of the COFs, metals, and coordination ligands. Specifically, permanent porosity, structural tunability, 2D conjugated structure, and heteroatoms in the building blocks of COFs are required for light harvesting, electron-hole separation/transportation, and the formation of a single site. The permanent porosity and enriched heteroatoms of COFs provide a special microenvironment that highly constrains single-sites by multi-chelation to promote charge transfer. Furthermore, the strategic utilization and combination of various building blocks with significant differences in electronegativity can effectively boost directional charge transfer owing to the inherent structural tunability of COFs. The planarity and high degree of conjugation of 2D crystalline COF endow them with excellent charge separation/transportation abilities and catalytic performance. In addition, the design of a single-site, including the metal and ligand, mainly lies in their rational selection, in which the chelation of ligands also plays a key role in charge transfer. Irrespective of whether the metal in a single-site comprises a single metal atom, metal ion, or complex for photocatalysis, it must also meet the thermodynamic and kinetic requirements of catalytic reactions. For electrocatalysis, apart from the identical characteristics of photocatalysis, conductivity, chemical stability, and adhesion on the electrode must be considered when designing COF-based single-site electrocatalysts. Considering these critical prerequisites for single-site catalysis, COF-based single-site catalysts can be designed and prepared by integrating rationally designed 2D COFs and single metal sites (Fig. 7 ). 4 COF-based single-site catalysts for photocatalysis and electrocatalysis COF-based single-site materials have garnered significant attention and exhibit great potential in the photo- and electrocatalytic fields owing to their unique advantages such as adjustable electronic properties, tunable single-site and COFs, and fully exposed catalytic active sites [100–102]. Therefore, COF-based single-site catalysts are regarded as potential materials for practical photo- and electrocatalytic applications. However, the applications of COF-based single-site photo- and electrocatalysts are still in development and several studies have been reported to date. These applications primarily involve photocatalysis for water splitting, photoreduction of CO2, production of H2O2, N2 fixation, degradation of contaminants, organic transformation, electrocatalytic H2 evolution, CO2 reduction, O2 reduction, O2 evolution, and N2 fixation (Fig. 8 ). In this section, we provide a comprehensive summary of the research progress in these areas. 4.1 COF-based single-site catalysts for Photocatalysis 4.1.1 Photocatalytic water splitting H2 is widely recognized as a highly promising energy source for replacing fossil fuels owing to its high calorific value and pollution-free characteristics. Photocatalytic H2 generation has gained significant attention as a sustainable and economic technology for harnessing solar energy and facilitating water-splitting process. H2 is generated by H+ reduction; however, it is difficult to directly evolve H2 from the COF, and co-catalysts are always employed. Co-catalysts can extract electrons or holes from photoexcited COFs and enhance the catalytic kinetics involved in H2 production. The pre-designed, crystalline, and tunable structures of COFs endow COF-based single-site catalysts with distinct advantages and immense potential for applications in photocatalytic H2 evolution compared to other inorganic or amorphous material [103–107]. An overview of COF-based single-sites for photocatalytic performance in H2 production and O2 evolution is presented in Table 1 . Dong et al. [108] reported the synthesis of atomic Pt-anchored 2D COFs (Fig. 9 ) for photocatalytic H2 production, utilizing special channels and dispersive N atoms to confine monoatomic Pt atoms. Through X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) measurements, it was confirmed that six coordinated C3N-Pt-Cl2 species were formed on TpPa-1-COF, resulting in excellent H2 production [108]. The coordinated structure of a single Pt atom with TpPa-1-COF contributed to the improvement in visible light absorption, charge separation, and interface reactions. The photogenerated electrons on TpPa-1-COF, with π conjugated structure, can transfer to the confined Pt single-atom, while the Pt single-atom acts as an active site to optimize the binding energy of transitional state (H*) generated from the reduction of the protons (H+) adsorbed from H2O dissociated, thus facilitating H2 release. Likewise, Li et al. [109] reported a method for in-situ photo deposition of Pt clusters on a COF (Pt/PY-DHBD-COF). The widespread Pt clusters strongly interact with the COF through coordination bonds, serving as active sites and facilitating photogenerated electron transfer. Finally, at 1 wt% Pt loading, the H2 evolution rate was 42 mmol g−1 h−1 [109]. Although incorporating atomic Pt into COFs results in excellent photocatalytic H2 evolution performance, the limited availability and high cost of Pt limits its extensive application. Nonprecious metals can serve as single sites for photocatalytic H2 production. Weng et al. [110] synthesized an atomically dispersed Cu(II)-coordinated chiral ketoenamine-linked COF (TpPa-Cu(II)-COF) for photocatalytic H2 production from water (Fig. 10 ). High concentrations of Cu(II) ions were atomically dispersed on the nodes of the hexagonal frameworks. These ions were coordinated by N-salicylideneaniline, in which photoinduced electrons could accumulate and transfer rapidly through the coordination of Cu ions. Further mechanistic investigations showed that the efficient transfer of excited electrons on TpPa-Cu(II)-COF, and the cascade reconstruction of a single site of Cu(II) to Cu(I), which is responsible for the superior photocatalytic H2 evolution, has been investigated extensively [110]. In addition, Ni(OH)2/TpPa-2 composites were designed for visible light-driven photocatalytic H2 production. The H2 production rate of the composite materials reached 1895.99 μmol g−1 h−1 [111]. This enhanced activity was ascribed to the synergistic effect of the uniformly distributed Ni(OH)2 and metallic Ni from the reduction of Ni(OH)2. Non-precious metals have great potential for the preparation of cost-effective COF-based single-site catalysts. Molecular complexes have been employed as single-sites in COFs for photocatalytic H2 evolution. Tanmay et al. [112] first reported an N2-COF with a molecular chloro(pyridine)cobaloxime complex for photocatalytic H2 production under simulated sunlight. Electrons are transported from the photoexcited COF to the Co complex, and then the protons are reduced to H2. In addition, [Mo3S13]2− nanoclusters were encapsulated in the pores of TpPa-1-COF for photocatalytic H2 production. The electron transfer process was confirmed by density functional theory (DFT) calculations, in which the N atoms in TpPa-1 donated electrons, while the S atom in the [Mo3S13]2− nanoclusters gained electrons. This electron transfer process facilitated the formation of H* and accelerated the release of H2 (Fig. 11 ) [113]. Metallic porphyrin-based COFs display promising performance in photocatalytic H2 evolution because of the conjugated π-electron of porphyrin and single-site metal center. Recently, a novel strategy for integrated interfacial design was explored and reported by Jiang et al. [114] to construct photocatalysts by using different combinations of molecular interfaces and stable COFs for H2 production. The authors adopted porphyrin as a knot and selected pyrazine or dihydroxyphenyl as functional linkers to prepare π-conjugated COFs (Fig. 12 ). The porphyrin knot and its ordered π skeletons enhance the light-harvesting efficiency and promote electron flow; the pyrazine linker acts as a coordination site to anchor non-noble metals, while the dihydroxyphenyl linker can control the hydrophilicity of pores to facilitate water delivery. These phenomenon collectively improve the photocatalytic performance. These results provide novel integrated interfacial design insights for the construction of efficient photocatalysts at molecular levels. Apart from the tuning of the organic units in COFs, the photocatalytic performance can also be tuned by the central metals in the porphyrin ring or by the coordination of the metals to the linkages [115,116]. In addition to the H2 production half-reaction, COF-based single-site materials have also been explored to conduct photocatalytic oxidation of water for the O2 evolution half-reaction. Theoretically, achieving oxidation of water into O2 first requires a positive potential greater than 1.23 eV, followed by a four-electron transfer process along with proton transfer [117]. However, achieving water oxidation to O2 remains a challenge and restricts the broader application of most reported semiconductors. Often, this necessitates the loading of cocatalysts or coupling with other oxidized materials. The easy modification and tunable band structures of COF-based single-site catalysts provide significant opportunities for realizing water oxidation; however, their applications remain limited. Xie et al. [118] utilized a highly ordered CTF-1 loaded with a RuOx cocatalyst to achieve H2O oxidation. The deeper valence band of CTF-1 induced a strong water oxidation ability, and the introduction of RuOx effectively improved the charge separation efficiency; thus, the RuO2/CTF-1 photocatalyst showed good O2 evolution performance. In addition, the incorporation of Co2+ into a COF as a single-site can enhance the photocatalytic evolution of O2 from H2O [119]. Significant photocatalytic activity for O2 generation (152 mol g−1 h−1) was achieved by modulating the Co content of COF-1. This can be ascribed to the improved light harvesting, suitable band position, and coordination interactions of Co2+ with Bp-COF. Recently, we reported a hydration-boosting water-oxidation pathway involving a single co-chelated COF for the generation of O2 [120]. Single Co sites were first chelated on the sites of the N and S atoms on BtB-COF by a coordination effect. Water dissociation was then achieved by hydration of the COF in water to form a [Co–OH] intermediate. The subsequent oxidative deprotonation, forming the [Co=O] intermediate, and intramolecular hydroxyl attack, forming O−O bonds, eventually led to the formation of O2 (Fig. 13 ). Considering the advantages of the Co@BtB-COF for water oxidation, a simple CdS/BtB-COF heterostructure was fabricated for photocatalytic water splitting. The production rates of H2 and O2 can reach 450 and 212 μmol g−1 h−1, respectively. The results not only provide a mechanistic insight into hydration-boosting water oxidation in COF-based single-site catalysts but also offer inspiration for the modification of COF-based single-site catalysts by constructing heterostructures, which further improves the overall photocatalytic reaction. Thus far, the overall photocatalytic water splitting with semiconductors has not reached satisfactory efficiency, primarily due to the stringent requirements for photocatalysts. However, COF-based single-site materials with pre-designed structures and functional groups show promise in achieving simultaneous H2 and O2 production, thereby completing the overall water splitting process. Combined with experimental and theoretical calculations, Tang et al. [121] regulated the synthesis of CTF-0 for water splitting and the production of H2 and O2 under visible light irradiation, which led to different interlayer structures, band positions, and N contents. The results indicate that CTF-0-M2 (prepared by microwave technology) with a higher N content and a more negative valence band position showed superior H2 production, whereas CTF-0-I (prepared by the ionothermal method) with higher amounts of benzene units exhibited good water oxidation to generate O2. Based on this, the coupling of CTF-0-M2 and CTF-0-I achieved overall water splitting. Apart from the CTFs materials, Yang and co-workers demonstrated overall water splitting by several 2D N-containing COFs, based on DFT calculations; the N site with lone pair electrons in COFs promoted H2 evolution, while the active sites in the benzene ring boosted O2 evolution [122]. A series of 2D COFs using nitrogen-linked functional groups as linkages was proposed and assembled. They exhibited theoretical potential for photocatalytic water splitting. Among these, a TST-based COF (I-TST) was synthesized, and it exhibited the ability to produce photocatalytic H2 and O2 (Figs. 14(a)–(c) ). Furthermore, the authors presented two possible 4e− OER reaction pathways on the TST segment of the COFs, namely single- and dual-site processes (Fig. 14(d)). The initial steps involving H2O dissociation and the formation of adsorbed OH (OH*) on the active sites of the benzene unit are common to both pathways. Subsequently, the photogenerated holes reduce the adsorbed O (O*). Different intermediate species are formed through single- and dual-site pathways, where the adsorbed OOH (OOH*) belongs to the single-site process, whereas the dual-site process exhibits the formation of O*OH*. After light irradiation, OO* is generated, leading to the release of the O2. The calculated Gibbs free energy results revealed that the dual-site pathway for the formation of O*OH* was thermodynamically more favorable than the single-site process for OOH* formation. Similarly, the H2 evolution was mainly dependent on the release of H* (Fig. 14(e)). These studies provide significant guidance for the development and preparation of feasible COFs photocatalysts for overall water splitting, and offer in-depth insights into the use of metal-free single N and C atoms as active sites in COF-based single-site catalysts. Apart from single N and C atoms that can be regarded as active sites in COFs for water splitting, recent research by Lan et al. demonstrated that single O and C sites in COFs can function as active sites for H2 and O2 evolution, respectively [123]. Specifically, Pt@TpBpy-NS and Pt@TpBpy-2-NS exhibited photocatalytic activity in overall water splitting. These materials consisted of β-ketoamine COFs nanosheets with in-situ incorporated Pt NPs as co-catalysts. A mechanistic study showed that the N position, COF morphology, and distribution of Pt in COFs are crucial factors for water splitting. According to theoretical calculations, photoelectrons can transfer from the Bpy fraction to the Tp fraction to efficiently drive the photocatalytic HER on the O sites of Tp in TpBpy-NS. However, the OER reaction can be assigned to the sp 2-hybridized C2 dual-site pathway on the Bpy segments of TpBpy-NS, according to the Gibbs free energy calculation (Fig. 15 ). This is similar to the dual-site process discussed above for the OER. These findings demonstrate the feasibility and potential of constructing of COF-based single-site catalysts for overall water splitting by regulating the atomic active sites. 4.1.2 Photocatalytic production of H2O2 In addition to the abovementioned photocatalytic HER and OER, the functional units in the COFs skeletons can also act as single-sites to drive photocatalytic water oxidation and/or oxygen reduction to produce H2O2. As illustrated in Fig. 16 , a series of hydrazone-linked COFs was fabricated for photocatalytic H2O2 production. The H2O2 generation rate was up to 1.0 mmol g−1 h−1 in pure water [124]. A novel hydration-induced water oxidation pathway was proposed based on in-situ characterization, experimental results, and theoretical calculations. The hydrazone unit in the COFs was identified as the active site for water hydration. The photoinduced electrons in the phenyl ring of the DETH unit are prone to transfer to the hydrazone groups in DETF-COF, leading to the separation of excitons. Subsequently, the final product of H2O2 was generated through the hydration reaction of water with an imine bond, formation of N-radicals and H2 by oxidative dehydrogenation, and coupling reaction of the dissociated OH radical. This study offers a novel metal-free water oxidation pathway for H2O2 production and provides guidance for the development of reversible bond-linked organic materials for photocatalytic water oxidation. Bipyridine-based COFs photocatalysts (COF-TfpBpy) also exhibit photocatalytic H2O2 production from water, in which the N atom in the bipyridine monomer is considered an active site that facilitates H2O2 production [125]. The existence of the bipyridine site induced high selectivity for the 2e− one-step reaction process (Fig. 17 ). In biphasic systems (benzyl alcohol and water), COFs with pyrene units are more active during photocatalytic H2O2 production than COF with bipyridine units under an O2 atmosphere [126]. In addition, some imine-linked [127,128] and triazine-based COFs [129,130] have been explored for photocatalytic H2O2 production via the ORR with sacrificial organic agents. COFs offer promising prospects for H2O2 production because of their tunable structures and numerous heteroatoms that serve as active sites for O2 and/or H2O activation and conversion. 4.1.3 Photocatalytic reduction of CO2 Atmospheric CO2 concentrations have continued to increase annually owing to expeditious exploitation. This has led to severe global warming and energy issues. The photocatalytic conversion of CO2 into other chemicals is a promising strategy that has attracted extensive research attention. However, it is difficult to activate and convert CO2 due of its chemical inertness. The photoreduction of CO2 involves multiple pathways to obtain multielectron reduction products (Fig. 18 ); the corresponding reduction potential must first be satisfied thermodynamically. Moreover, kinetics of the reaction also play a crucial role in determining the selectivity of the products. Traditional semiconductors, which are commonly used in photocatalysis, still face limitations in terms of structural regulation [131]. COF-based single-site photocatalysts with tunable structures and enriched catalytically active sites are promising for CO2 reduction. By utilizing a single site as an active center, these catalysts can promote the dynamic process and lower the reaction energy barriers. Significant endeavors have been made and reported to date. The photocatalytic activities of the COF-based single-site catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . In 2019, we designed and incorporated a Ni complex as a single-site in a TpBpy COF (Ni-TpBpy) for the photoreduction of CO2 to CO (Fig. 19 ). The cooperation of a single Ni site and the TpBpy COF effectively improved the photoreduction performance of CO2, as evidenced by experimental and DFT calculations. The bipyridine units and keto knots in TpBpy can efficiently stabilize single Ni sites and enhance CO2 adsorption, activation, and conversion [132]. The proposed reaction mechanism for Ni-TpBpy involved the excitation of Ru(bpy)3 2+ by visible light, which subsequently transferred electrons to the Ni site to reduce CO2 molecules. This study highlights COF-based single-site photocatalysis for the photoreduction of CO2 and provides useful guidance for the regulation of catalytically active sites via coordination interactions. We integrated polyimide-based COFs (PI-COFs) with molecular Ni complexes for the photoreduction of CO2 to CO (Fig. 20 ) [133]. The molecular Ni complex acts as a single-site for CO2 reduction, while the PI-COFs can be considered as photosensitizers and functionalized hosts. The hot electrons in the central ring of the COFs could transfer from the diimide linkage to the single Ni sites through intra- and intermolecular electron transfer pathways, for the efficient photoreduction of CO2. Recently, a series of bipyridine-based COFs that immobilize different metal single sites, including Co, Re, Ru, Mo, and Cu, was synthesized for photocatalytic CO2 reduction using a similar mechanism [134–140]. In addition to the bipyridine fraction, other COFs with coordination sites can be used to anchor metal ions or clusters to build COF-based single-site catalysts for the photoreduction of CO2. Lan and co-workers prepared transition-metal ion-modified COFs to reduce CO2 to CO or HCOOH (Fig. 21 ) [141]. Metal ions serve as the active sites for photocatalytic activity. Different metal ions can affect the selectivity of the reduced products. DQTP COF-Co displayed superior CO evolution activity, while DQTP COF-Zn showed the HCOOH generation. N3-COF with bimetallic PdIn nanoclusters (PdxIny@N3-COF) exhibited photocatalytic CO2 conversion to CH3OH and CH3CH2OH via H2O oxidation [142]. The synergetic effect between the bimetallic nanoclusters and N3-COF effectively promoted interfacial electron transfer, thus realizing efficient CO2 conversion to C1/C2 products. In addition, polyoxometalate (POM) clusters serving as single sites confined in COFs have been used for the photoreduction of CO2 with H2O. The synergistic interaction between the metal clusters and COF enabled superior CO2 reduction activity and selectivity (Fig. 22 ) [143]. Similarly, in a recent study by Lan et al. [144], a crystalline heterometallic cluster photocatalyst (MOF-Ti6Cu3) exhibited a superior photocatalytic activity up to 169.8 μmol g−1 h−1 in the reduction of CO2 to HCOOH (Fig. 23 ). The resulting MOF-Ti6Cu3 catalyst was linked via dynamic covalent bonds. This facilitated significant electron transfer within the framework. The Cu and Ti clusters in MOF-Ti6Cu3 serve as single reactive sites, in which the Cu clusters gain photoelectrons from the Ti clusters to reduce CO2 to HCOOH, and the holes in the Ti clusters oxidize H2O to O2 [144]. Metallic porphyrin-based COFs featuring N-cooperating single metal ions have been explored for the photocatalytic reduction of CO2. The oxidation state of the porphyrinic metals was found to greatly influence their activity and product selectivity for CO2 reduction. Combined with experimental and DFT calculation results, Jiang et al. [145] illustrated that COF367-CoIII showed more favorable activity and selectivity in the photocatalytic CO2 reduction of HCOOH than COF-367-CoII (Figs. 24(a) and (b) ). Porphyrinic tetrathiafulvalene-based COFs, prepared using metallized TAPP-M (M = 2H, Zn, Ni, and Cu) and TTF monomers, exhibited overall photoreduction activity for CO2 (Figs. 24(c)–(e)). The superior performance was attributed to the efficient charge transfer process in TTCOFs, in which the photoelectrons were impelled to the single metal active sites in the porphyrin unit for CO2 reduction reactions (CO2RR). Because of the covalent coupling interaction in TTCOFs between porphyrin and tetrathiafulvalene, the photoinduced holes in TTF can be used to oxidize H2O to O2. Among all the as-prepared COFs, TTCOF-Zn achieved excellent CO evolution with ~100% selectivity together with stoichiometric O2 evolution [146]. Carbon dots containing metal porphyrin molecules can also be incorporated as single-sites into COFs for the photoreduction of CO2. Ni-PCD@TD-COF was prepared by filling Ni-porphyrin-based carbon dots into TD-COF, which exhibited outstanding photocatalytic CO2 reduction activity [147]. The catalytic activity can be optimized by replacing the building blocks with electronic donor-acceptor units in metallic porphyrin-based COFs [62,148–151]. PD-COF-23-Ni [62] and CoPor-DPP-COF [150] with donor-acceptor units can drive the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 without an additional photosensitizer. In addition, 2D COF nanosheets with extended conjugated structures and atomic thicknesses often exhibit distinctive physical and chemical properties compared to their bulk counterparts, rendering them highly appealing for applications in photocatalysis. Cooper et al. [152] prepared a series of single Co-loaded COF nanosheets (CONs) for photocatalytic CO2 reduction. Single Co sites were confined by the pyridine and imine groups in CONs, and the resultant Co-FPy-CON exhibited outstanding photocatalytic activity because of the fully exposed active sites. Fang et al. [153] reported the synthesis of Co- and Ni-coordinated guanidinium-based CONs for the photoreduction of CO2 to CO, where Co-based photocatalysts exhibited better CO production activity. The Co2+ in TFBD-COF also exhibits good photocatalytic CO2 reduction performance [154]. Bi-chelating Ni sites anchored on CON photocatalysts (Ni-TP-CON) were designed for the selective photoreduction of CO2 to CO [155]. Metal chelation contributes to decreasing the energy barrier and promotes carrier transport to form key *COOH intermediates in the photoreduction process. CTFs have also been reported and used as supporters to confine single-atom active sites, such as Pt, Co, Fe, and Cu, in which single atoms can act as reaction centers, mediate electron transport, activate CO2 molecules, and enhance the performance of the photoreduction of CO2 [156–163]. Bi et al. [156,157] confined single Pt and Cu atoms in CTFs for the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CH4. The precise arrangement of Pt-N and Cu-N sites in CTFs was confirmed by extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) characterizations, demonstrating an enhanced CO2 activation ability. In addition, the incorporation of Fe atoms into Tr-COF also achieved remarkable activity in the photoreduction of CO2 to CO. The synergistic effect between single Fe sites and COFs played a vital role in reducing the energy barriers for the formation of crucial *COOH intermediates (Fig. 25 ) [163]. 4.1.4 Photocatalytic N2 fixation Semiconductor-based photocatalytic technology is emerging as an important sustainable approach in the reduction of N2 for ammonia (NH3) production, as compared to the conventional Haber-Bosch technology. The mechanism of N2 fixation (N2 + 3H2 → 2NH3) mainly involves three aspects: adsorption of N2, electron transfer, and triple bonds weakening, ultimately leading to the reduction of N2 into NH3. The robustness of the triple bonds in N2 poses considerable challenges in the reduction process, necessitating catalysts with high capabilities and even the introduction of co-catalysts. Therefore, COF-based single-site catalysts that encapsulate single active sites as reactive centers can promote the reduction of N2 into NH3. While COF-based single-site catalysts have been extensively employed in the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 reduction and water, their utilization in the photocatalytic reduction of N2 has been comparatively limited. Moreover, the application of COF-based single-site materials in photocatalytic N2 fixation is still far fewer than that for CO2 and water photo-oxidation-reduction over COF-based single-site photocatalysts. Zhong et al. [167] prepared Pt-SAC/CTF, where a single Pt atom was coordinated to the N3 sites in a CTF nanosheet. The presence of Pt-N3 architecture in Pt-SACs/CTF was proved and analyzed by HAADF-STEM and EXAFS tests, as well as DFT calculations. Pt-SACs/CTF exhibited an excellent NH3 generation rate of 171.4 μmol g−1 h−1 without additive sacrificial agents. The single Pt atom accelerates electron-hole pair separation in the CTF and facilitates electron transfer from the CTF to the single Pt atoms, leading to the reduction of N2 to NH3 (Figs. 26(a)–(d) ) [167]. Proton-coupled electron process (PCET) was employed to propose and validate two possible mechanisms for the formation of N2: the distal and alternating mechanisms, as confirmed by DFT calculations (Fig. 26(e)). The two mechanisms differ in the protonation process; in the distal mechanism, the release of NH3 can be ascribed to the protonation of one N atom of nitrogen, whereas in the other both N atoms of N2 are alternatively protonated. The calculation results showed that the alternating mechanism of N2 fixation was more favorable. This study pioneered the strategy and mechanism of anchoring single atoms to COFs for photocatalytic N2 fixation. In addition, recent investigations have focused on porphyrin-based COFs as docking sites, where light-harvesting antennae were utilized to anchor single Au atoms for photocatalytic N2 fixation. The activity center microenvironment of the Au single atom was accurately tuned at the molecular level by adjusting the functional group species, and the as-obtained COF1-Au catalyst with strong electron-withdrawing groups exhibited superior NH3 production [168]. In addition, boron atom-doped Tp-bpy-COF was speculated to reduce N2 to NH3 by DFT calculation [169]. The B atom could effectively activate N2 through the synergistic effect of B-N. Bi et al. [170] constructed imine-linked COF-TaTp and interspersed it with Bi NPs (Bi/COF-TaTp) to boost charge transfer and N2 activation by considering the coordination interaction of N-Bi-O and achieved superior photocatalytic activity for N2 fixation and conversion to NH3 (Fig. 27 ). Isotope labeling experiments confirmed that the generation of NH4 + originates from N2 fixation. DFT calculations indicated that incorporation of Bi NPs can effectively activate N2 by increasing the electron density of π*-orbital and suppress the competing reaction of HER, thereby exhibiting excellent NH3 generation performance. These studies offer the possibility of dispersing metal-free or non-noble metals on COFs to fabricate COF-based single-site catalysts for application in photocatalytic N2 fixation. However, the application of a COF-based single site for photocatalytic N2 fixation is currently in its initial stages. Considering the unique advantages of COFs and the promising potential in this field, it is believed that more COF-based single-site catalysts will be explored in photocatalytic N2 fixation. 4.1.5 Photocatalytic degradation of contaminants Additionally, COF-based single-site materials have been used for the photocatalytic degradation of contaminants. Apart from meeting the common photocatalytic prerequisites, contaminant degradation is usually related to the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) such as superoxide (O2 •–) or hydroxyl (O2 •–) radicals. Furthermore, the affinity between contaminants and catalytic materials plays an essential role in contaminant degradation. Therefore, COF-based single-site catalysts with similar chemical components and tunable band structures offer an emerging platform for the photocatalytic degradation of contaminants. Terpyridyl-based COF nanorods integrated with a single Cu-site photocatalyst (COF-909(Cu)) were rationally designed and used for photocatalytic sulfamethoxazole (SMX) degradation. According to this study, the incorporation of single Cu sites enhanced the separation efficiency of charge carriers and provided enriched active sites for photocatalytic degradation [171]. As validated by DFT calculations, the distribution of photoelectrons and holes in COF-909(Cu) can be separated more efficiently compared to that in COF-909 (Fig. 28 ). Meanwhile, the generation of surface ROS, such as OH• and O2 •– can be considered the main active components in COF-909(Cu) for SMX degradation. Noble-metal NPs have multiple advantages in the photocatalytic degradation of pollutants. Li and co-workers successfully prepared AgNPs@NCOF for the reduction of 4-nitrophenol. Ag NPs served as active sites, whereas the COFs provided suitable nucleation sites and abundant N atoms for the formation of Ag NPs [172]. Electron transfer from the COF to the metal NPs enriches the electron density, and the COF inhibits the aggregation of the NPs, thus promoting catalysis. 4.1.6 Photocatalytic organic transformation Owing to their unique advantages, COF-based single-site catalysts have shown significant progress in photocatalytic organic transformations mainly involving oxidation reactions, C–H activation, hydrogenation, and dehydrogenation, among others. Single metal sites and/or organic units are considered as active sites in organic transformations. Jiang et al. [173] constructed porphyrin-based COFs (DhaTph-M, M = 2H, Zn, Ni) for photocatalytic terpinene oxidation, in which the different metal active centers in the porphyrin acted as regulators to adjust the excitonic effects and promote the conversion of singlets and dissociation of excitons. The obtained DhaTph-Zn and DhaTph-Ni exhibited different photocatalytic products, activities, and selectivities for terpinene oxidation, owing to the different ROS generated. Among them, Zn2+ in DhaTph-Zn primarily facilitate the conversion of singlets and energy transfer, along with the activation of O2 to 1O2 and hydroxylation of boronic acid. Meanwhile, Ni2+ in DhaTph-Ni boost the dissociation of excitons and charge transfer and generates O2 •– from O2 molecules and exhibit excellent performance in the oxidation of sulfides (Fig. 29(a) ). This study not only provides important insights into molecular oxygen activation and the adjustment of excitonic effects but also offers significant guidance for production selectivity by adjusting the metal types in COF-based single-site catalysts for photocatalytic organic transformation. In addition to metallic porphyrin-based COFs, C–H activation also occurs. Ru-COF, synthesized by the chelation of Ru ions on COFs by bpy sites, produces indolylglycine via cross-dehydrogenative coupling upon visible light irradiation [174]. The reaction mechanism followed a single electron transfer controlled by a radical pathway via in-situ generation of an iminium ion intermediate (Fig. 29(b)). The Pt@COF reported by Aleman et al. [175], which incorporated photoactive Pt(II) into imine-based COF, could trigger the oxidation of sulfide into sulfoxides through simultaneous energy and electron transfer processes. CTFs can be explored as metal-free photocatalysts for photocatalytic organic transformations, in which functional organic units act as single sites. Thiophen-containing CTF (CTF-Th) showed photocatalytic oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes using an O2 oxidant [176]. The thiophene units can greatly enhance the photo-oxidation nature of the CTF and achieve superior photocatalytic efficiency. Benzoxazole-linked COFs synthesized by Wang et al. [87] performed well in the photocatalytic transformation of 4-carboxyphenylboronic acid with O2. The introduction of the benzoxazole units effectively decreased the bandgap and promoted the utilization of visible light. Studies of the reaction mechanism showed that the generation of 4-hydroxybenzoic acid by transforming 4-carboxyphenylbor- onic acid followed a O2 •– radical pathway. O2 •− was generated by excited LZU-190 (Fig. 30 ). In summary, COF-based single-site catalysts have sparked wide interest in photocatalysis. The common photocatalytic mechanisms of various catalytic reactions are related to thermodynamics and kinetics and primarily involve light absorption, charge transfer, and surface reduction/oxidation processes. The enhancement of catalytic activity not only correlates with the intrinsic properties of photocatalysts, but also lies in the precise regulation of active sites, which are crucial for improving the charge transfer efficiency and inducing surface reactions. COF-based single-site photocatalysts are expected to become widely used in photocatalysis. 4.2 COF-based single-site catalyst for electrocatalysis 4.2.1 Electrocatalytic H2 evolution Sustainable hydrogen generation is critical for the future hydrogen economy. Hydrogen can be generated via water splitting when a current was applied [177,178]. Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) follows different pathways, involving Volmer pathway (H+ + e−+ * → H*), Heyrovsky pathway (H+ + e−+ H* → H2), and Tafel pathway 2H* → H2 + 2*, * Refers to active site in catalysts. Generally, the activity from COFs-based electrocatalysts can be ascribed to three different types of active centers: (1) metal atom sites, (2) metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) sites, and (3) N-dopant heteroatoms. Next, we will elaborate on the progress of COFs-based electrocatalysts in HER. Noble metals, such as Pt, are one of the most active catalysts for HER. However, their low cost-effectiveness limited their large-scale application [179,180]. Later, lots of electrocatalysts based on transition metals have also been developed, yet, stability is their major obstacle [181–183]. Qiao et al. [184] reported CTFs@MoS2 composite electrocatalysts for HER (Fig. 31 ), which shows superior catalytic activity, as evidenced by their low overpotential (93 mV) and small Tafel slope (43 mV dec−1). Thanks to the natural p-conjugated crystal channels, CTF can help with mass- and electron-transfer in HER process. The kinetics analysis results show that the excellent HER performance is attributed to to the hierarchical pore structures and aggregation of MoS2 NPs. Single metal sites could be developed by introducing metalloporphyrins structures into porous materials [185,186]. Recently, Yi et al. [187] incorporated Co porphyrin-like units into porous CTFs through an ionothermal synthesis technique to prepare CoSAs/PTF catalysts (Fig. 32 ). CoSAs were identified by HAADF-STEM images. It is worth noting that single atom catalysts CoSAs/PTF-600 exhibited much higher HER activity than PTF-600, (Co)PTF-600, and CoNPs/PTF-600, which indicates that CoSAs played a major role in HER. Moreover, Fig. 32(d) shows that Tafel slope of CoSAs is low to 50 mV dec−1, and is close to the Pt/C benchmark (33 mV dec−1). When normalized by the mass loaded, CoSAs/PTF-600 shows higher activity than Pt/C benchmark, suggesting an efficient metal utilization of CoSAs/PTF-600. 4.2.2 Electrocatalytic CO2 reduction It is widely accepted that three steps are usually involved in an electrochemical CO2RR process: (1) the adsorption of CO2 onto active sites of catalysts; (2) electrons and protons transferred to the adsorbed CO2; and (3) the desorption of products. Bonding affinity between CO2/final products and COF-based materials can be optimized by their tunable active sites so that CO2 activation and product dissociation could be promoted simultaneously. The porous structure of COFs exposed more sites for reaction. Besides, by careful selection of building blocks, the ability of electron transportation and mass transfer could be subtly regulated. All of the above characteristics of COFs make them good candidates for electrocatalytic CO2RR [49]. For instance, M-N-C catalysts, derived from COFs, have been demonstrated suitable for CO2RR. By pyrolysis of COFs@LDH, Lin et al. [188] prepared CoN2O2 sites in 2D carbon (2D-Co-COF) for CO2RR, which had abundant active sites (Fig. 33 ). The 2D-Co-COF500 catalysts showed an extraordinary catalytic capability towards CO2RR, with a FECO reaching 96.5%. DFT calculations and the partial density of states (PDOS) indicated that the formation of COOH* is believed to be the rate-determining step (RDS). Co centers favors the cleavage and stretching of COOH*, thus COOH* formation could be accelerated on CoN2O2 sites. The composite integrated with metallophthalocyanine (MPc) and COFs also shows a promising electrocatalytic CO2RR performance. Jiang et al. [189] reported a 2D polyimide-linked phthalocyanine COFs (CoPc-PI-COFs), which gave a high CO2-to-CO conversion selectivity up to 97% in 0.5 mol L−1 KHCO3 electrolyte (Fig. 34 ). The corresponding Gibbs free energy calculation, including *COOH and *CO formation, and *CO desorption, clarified the possible reaction pathways. Compared with CoPc, the composite catalysts CoPc-PI-COF-1 and CoPc-PI-COF-2 showed lower energy barrier, and thus were more conducive to CO2RR. Moreover, as verified by both experimental results and DFT calculation, the superior performance was believed to be correlated to the porosity and π-π stacking structure of phthalocyanine-tetramine units, which facilitated the mass transfer and electron transportation. This work strongly emphasized the superiority and the application potential of phthalocyanine COFs-based single-site electrocatalysts with excellent stability and electroconductivity toward electrocatalytic CO2RR. 4.2.3 Electrocatalytic O2 reduction Due to its potential applications in H2-O2 fuel cells, electrocatalytic O2 reduction reaction (ORR) is extensively studied [70]. Noble metals are thought to be the best catalysts for ORR. But their low cost-efficiency limited the large-scale application. Anchoring noble metals on a support is a promising method to obtain a cost-effective and efficient catalyst. Kazuhide et al. [190] prepared Pt-modified CTFs (Pt-CTFs) and a composite catalyst consisting of the as-prepared Pt-CTFs and carbon NPs (Pt-CTFs/CPs), which exhibited high electrocatalytic activity for ORR. Specifically, for single Pt sites, oxygen molecules can be adsorbed on Pt sites via either the Griffiths model (side-on adsorption) [191] or the Pauling model (end-on adsorption) [192]. The O 2π orbitals provide π electrons to the unoccupied Pt 5d orbitals while simultaneously accepting π* electrons from the occupied Pt 5d orbitals, thereby activating the O–O bond. Therefore, the introduction of single Pt sites in CTFs can be responsible for the enhancement of electrocatalytic ORR in acidic solutions over Pt-CTFs. Besides, the Pt-CTFs were also active for hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR), and outperformed the Pt/C benchmark, indicating that Pt-CTFs could be a bifunctional catalyst for fuel cells [193]. To maximize atom utilization, N-coordinated porous SACs were designed for ORR, which could be a promising approach. Luis et al. [194] fabricated two different Co(II)-porphyrin [2,1,3]-benzothiadiazole (BTD)-based COFs for ORR (Fig. 35 ). Mass activity results at 0.85 V vs. RHE show that Co@rhm-PorBTD and Co@sql-PorBTD surpassed Pt/C benchmark by 5.8 times and 1.3 times, respectively. The formation of OOH* from O2 was deemed as the RDS for ORR reaction over Co@rhm-PorBTD and Co@sql-PorBTD affirmed by DFT calculation. Recently, metal-free heteroatom-doped carbon catalysts have received broad attention for ORR due to their low cost. Yang et al. [195] reported the synthesis of 2D COFs-derived N, P co-doped carbons. Uniformly distributed N and P atoms are obtained as efficient electrocatalytic active sites after graphitization (Fig. 36(a) ). The N, P co-doped carbon catalyst exhibits good electrochemical performance due to its nanopores, which could promote mass transfer (Fig. 36(b)). Moreover, their catalytic capabilities remain unaltered after a prolonged test (Fig. 36(c)). These findings provide possibilities for exploring more robust COF-derived metal-free catalysts for energy conversion applications. 4.2.4 Electrocatalytic O2 evolution Electrocatalytic oxygen evolution reaction (OER), the reverse process of ORR, involves 4e− transfer. The OER is considered as a crucial process in water splitting and CO2RR. The achievement of OER over COFs is more challengeable than HER, ORR, and CO2RR because of their intrinsic organic chemical properties. The main challenges that affect the stability of COF are self-oxidation and hydrolysis. Even so, a few of recent studies using COF as metal supporters enable the electrocatalytic OER. The conjugated framework contributes the oxidation stability. Kurungot et al. [196] manipulated Co(II) ions into the pores of a bipyridine containing COF (TpBpy) (Fig. 37 ). The XRD pattern demonstrates that the COF structure is retained after Co modification. Co-TpBpy exhibits a surface area as large as 450 m2 g−1 and remarkable activity/stability. Specifically, under neutral pH conditions, Co-TpBpy shows a low overpotential of only 400 mV for OER at the current density of 1 mA cm−2. Besides, very recently, according to DFT calculation and experimental results, different transition metal anchored COF-C4N nanosheet catalysts were proposed to be suitable for electrocatalytic OER [197]. The OER reaction mechanism and reaction pathway were proposed based on the calculations of Gibbs free energy and PDOS calculation (Fig. 38 ). When the applied potential is U = 0 V, it can be seen that for Co-COF-C4N catalyst, the RDS is the conversion of *O to *OOH, while for Ni-COF-C4N catalyst, the RDS is the conversion of *OH to *O. Due to the higher free energy change of the RDS (1.89 eV) for Co-COF-C4N catalyst, the OER reaction on Co-COF-C4N should require a higher starting potential bias U to overcome the energy barrier. The calculated PDOS showed strong coupling between the O 2p state and the metal 3d state near the Fermi level in both Ni-COF-C4N and Co-COF-C4N catalysts, mainly contributed by O py and 3d yz orbitals. The hybridization between metal 3d and O 2p orbitals lowered the hybridized energy level below the Fermi level (E f), leading to antibonding energy below E f. The *OOH adsorption strength was determined by the filling of bonding states. Where, there were more antibonding states below E f, the weaker the adsorption strength was. Compared to Ni-COF-C4N, Co-COF-C4N had fewer antibonding states below E f, resulting a stronger *OOH adsorption affinity. Additionally, the charge density differences between the metal sites and the *OOH intermediate were calculated in Ni-COF-C4N and Co-COF-C4N catalysts. Because of the strong d-pπ coupling between Co 3d orbitals and O 2pz orbitals, 0.44 |e| electrons were transferred from *OOH to Co atoms, while only 0.40 |e| electrons were transferred from *OOH to Ni atoms. Therefore, more positive charges were accumulated on *OOH sites of Co-COF-C4N catalyst, which could be helpful to activate H2O and release O2. The diversity and designability enable COFs to be promising candidates in applications of OER although it is still in its infancy. 4.2.5 Electrocatalytic N2 fixation The Haber-Bosch process, which is an energy- and capital-intensive process, is the dominant method for the production of synthetic ammonia. Recently, energy-efficient and environmentally friendly electrocatalytic N2 reduction reactions (NRRs) for ammonia synthesis have received considerable attention [198]. Jiang et al. [199] introduced transition metal centers into a conjugated 2D COF to enhance its electrocatalytic NRR activity (Fig. 39 ). Ti-COF exhibits higher NRR activity than Cu-COF and Co-COF because Ti metal can activate N2 and suppress side reactions, such as the HER. Ti-COF also shows a high FE of 34.62%, with NH3 yield reaching 26.89 μg mg−1 cat h−1. Similarly, according to DFT calculations, other types of metals, such as Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta, and W, were also designed and incorporated into Co-based COFs to elaborate on the application potential of the electrocatalytic NRR [200]. The NRR reaction pathways proposed for the as-obtained COFs include alternating, distal, consecutive, enzymatic, and mixed pathways, in which the Nb-COFs follow consecutive, enzymatic, or mixed mechanisms for the NRR because of the lateral adsorption of N2. However, Mo-COFs and Ta-COFs comply with alternating, distal, or mixed mechanisms owing to their end-on N2 adsorption configuration (Fig. 40(a) ). Specifically, for Nb-COFs, the NRR pathway involves the sequential conversion of NNH to NNH2 and then to NH3. Following the formation of the first NH3 molecule, the other N atom undergoes three consecutive hydrogenation steps to produce the second NH3 molecule. It is evident that the N2 reduction proceeds via a sequential mechanism. The potential-determining step (PDS) is **N2 + H+ + e− → *N*NH (Fig. 40(b)). In contrast, for the Mo-COF catalyst (Fig. 40(c)), after the initial hydrogenation step to form NNH, another proton-coupled electron attacks *NNH to form the *NNH2 intermediate. Subsequently, the *NNH2 intermediate undergoes a distal reaction to sequentially form *N, *NH, NH2, and NH3. In this case, the PDS was *N2 + H+ + e− → *NNH. The NRR on the Ta-COFs (Fig. 40(d)) and Mo-COFs share the first two hydrogenation steps. However, in the third step, *NHNH2 intermediate was formed. The NRR of the Ta-COFs proceeds through a mixed mechanism. Collectively, this work opens a new avenue for designing 2D COFs catalysts with abundant coordination centers for highly efficient NRR and provides useful insights into the NRR mechanism. In summary, the use of COF-based single-site catalysts for H2 evolution, CO2 reduction, O2 reduction, O2 evolution, and N2 fixation is still in its infancy. COFs have exhibited great application potential in these processes owing to their large surface area, tunable pore size, and pre-designable functional groups. The representative COF-based single-site catalysts are summarized in Table 3 . 5 In-situ characterization methods of COF-based single-site catalyst In recent years, in-situ technologies have emerged as an important characterization method to monitor continuous catalytic processes in real time, which play an essential role in revealing the dynamic evolution of active sites [142,163,201]. Some in-situ characterization methods, such as in-situ DRIFT and in-situ XPS, have been utilized to investigate the charge transfer pathways of COF-based single-site catalysts and further reveal the critical roles of single-sites in COF-based catalysis [124,144]. For instance, according to the in-situ DRIFT spectra, C–OH signal peak in DETH-COF the emerged and gradually increased. This peal indicates the formation of an adduct of H2O to the hydrazone-based COF, providing strong evidence in support of the proposed water oxidation pathway (Fig. 41(a) ) [124]. Furthermore, the catalytic process for the photocatalytic reduction of CO2 was explored by the in-situ DRIFT spectra (Fig. 41(b)). With prolonged irradiation, the characteristic signals of the key reaction intermediates and their increased intensities reveal the formation mechanism of HCOOH [144]. In addition, in-situ XPS was employed to study the changes in metal element valance states and charge transfer routes during the photocatalytic process. For instance, the valence states of Ti6 and Cu3 in MCOF-Ti6Cu3 and charge-transfer pathway can be determined by exploring the valence change via the in-situ XPS measurements (Fig. 42 ). Specifically, upon light irradiation, the Ti 2p binding energy increased, while that of Cu 2p decreased. This indicates that the electrons could be captured by the Cu cluster site for the CO2 reduction reaction, whereas the Ti clusters act as oxidative sites for water oxidation. In addition to the common in-situ technologies mentioned above, other advanced in-situ techniques such as in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), in-situ electron spin resonance (ESR), and in-situ TEM are expected to be explored to investigate the dynamic changes in COFs and single active sites in catalysis [201]. In addition, these in-situ characterization techniques usually need to be performed in conjunction with theoretical calculations to further ascertain the effect of a single site in COFs and affirm the catalytic mechanism, which has become a promising tool in photo- and electrocatalysis. 6 Theoretical calculations in COF-based single-site catalysis 6.1 Theoretical calculations for photocatalysis DFT calculations are a promising strategy not only for designing functional COFs but also for investigating the catalytic mechanism. In cutting-edge research, it is essential to define the structure of catalytic active sites and reveal reaction mechanisms to build structure-activity relationships to further improve the catalytic performance [169,202]. The remarkable advantages of the definite structures and easy modular synthesis of COFs make them ideal candidates for the calculations. Precise active sites, charge densities, and reaction pathways can be calculated and speculated by DFT calculations, to establish a reliable structure-activity relationship. To verify the feasibility of overall photocatalytic water splitting driven by N-linked COFs, the geometric structures of the model COF compounds were first developed by a topological method, and their electronic band structures and Gibbs free energy changes were calculated by DFT calculations [122]. In addition to the structural feasibility, the calculated results contributed to the identification of the active sites. Compared with single-site reactions in 2D COFs, dual-site reaction processes were determined to be more energetically feasible, based on the calculated Gibbs free energy values of the key intermediate states in the rate-limiting step. Lan et al. performed theoretical calculations and experimental research on Pt@TpBpy-COF, [123] which illustrated that the incorporation of Pt NPs, nanosheet morphology of COFs, directional charge transfer, and single-site or dual-site reaction pathways collectively influenced the overall photocatalytic water splitting. In particular, time-dependent DFT calculations revealed the charge-transfer characteristics of the TpBpy-COFs. In addition, charge distribution and charge density differences can be estimated using DFT calculations to investigate the charge distribution and transfer regulated by a single-site. As shown in Fig. 43(a) , the encapsulation of a single Cu site in Bpy-COF can effectively promote charge separation and enable electrons to accumulate around the single Cu site, boosting the photocatalytic activity. [140]. Likewise, two reaction mechanisms for photocatalytic N2 fixation over the Pt-SAC/CTF catalysts, namely distal and alternating mechanisms, were explored and confirmed by DFT calculations. The corresponding geometric structures were simultaneously established and obtained (Fig. 43(b)). 6.2 Theoretical calculations for electrocatalysis DFT calculations are conducive for understanding the catalytic mechanism of catalysts in COFs electrocatalysis. Specific steps and intermediate species in the CO2RR can be studied by using DFT calculations to simulate the CO2RR. DFT calculations, to simulate the CO2RR with CoN3O and CoN4 as experimental controls, were employed to further explore the roles of the CoN2O2 sites of the COF in the CO2RR [188]. They found that the process of CO2RR includes the formation of *COOH and *CO through single-electron transfer mechanisms, followed by CO desorption (Figs. 44(a) and 44(b) ). Furthermore, DFT calculations are valuable tools for the speculation of different activities in various electrocatalysts, such as metal-based and metal-free catalysts [169,203–205]. For example, to investigate the electrochemical HER mechanism, the ΔG H* of the HER was simulated using DFT calculations [206]. The calculated results indicate that the Co site has a lower free energy than Zn, Cu, Ni, Fe, and Mn in the Salen complexes for the HER (Figs. 44(c) and (d)). Briefly, by regulating the electronic structure of single-metal-site catalysts, the free energy of Hads can be optimized to promote the HER. COF-C4N was designed using DFT calculations for the electrocatalytic OER [207]. The combination of theoretical calculations and experimental results indicated that the crystallinity and stability of the COFs, suitable band gap, and N positions related to the C active sites in COF-C4N endowed COF-C4N with better OER performance. In summary, theoretical calculations are important for identifying the structure of catalytically active sites and investigating the reaction pathway for COF-based single-site catalysts. More importantly, the combination of theoretical calculations and experiments displays widespread application potential in photo- and electrocatalysis, where theoretical calculations can guide the design of function-targeted COFs and provide a deeper understanding of catalysis at the molecular level. 7 Modification strategies of COF-based single-site catalyst 7.1 Modification strategies for photocatalysis In addition to the encapsulation of single sites into COFs, the integration of heterogeneous components with COF is a promising strategy for constructing heterojunctions in COF-based single-site catalysts. Charge carrier separation and transfer efficiency in photocatalysis can be enhanced in heterostructures [208–212]. To date, owing to the abundance of heteroatoms in COF frameworks capable of coordinating with metals, researchers have employed various semiconductors to couple with COFs. These semiconductors include metal sulfides and oxides, MOFs, g-C3N4, and metal-based co-catalysts [213–221], which can effectively improve charge separation and enhance the accessibility of active sites, resulting in excellent photocatalytic performance. According to the band position of COFs, TiO2, and MOFs, COF-based multicomponent nanocomposites can be precisely designed and constructed for artificial photosynthesis. Lan et al. [221] demonstrated that the incorporation of three components provides multiple active sites, inducing fast charge transfer and wide light absorption (Fig. 45 ). The charge carrier separation efficiency was enhanced, which was attributed to the successful design of the Z-scheme and II-type heterostructures in the multicomponent COF-based nanocomposites. The reduction reaction of CO2 was conducted on the Ni sites of COF-366-Ni-OH, whereas the oxidation was completed in TiO2.
