This novel design strategy for the photocatalyst was based on the structural features of the COFs, which opens new avenues for the development of highly efficient catalysts. 7.2 Modification strategies for electrocatalysis In electrocatalysis, constructing heterostructures is also a promising strategy for boosting the electrocatalytic activity of COF-based single-site catalysts, in which the formation of heterojunctions can enhance the electron transfer efficiency. For example, COF@ZIF-67 derived core-shell structured carbon electrocatalysts with uniformly dispersed Co nanoparticles and Co-N4 active sites were synthesized for the electrocatalytic ORR and HER [222]. The formation of the COF shell effectively inhibited the collapse and aggregation of ZIF-67 during TP-BPY-COF@ZIF-67 pyrolysis, promoted mass transport, and enhanced the electron conductivity, owing to the high degree of graphitization (Fig. 46 ). This strategy offers a new platform for the design and fabrication of COFs and MOFs hybrid catalysts for electrochemical energy conversion and storage applications. Therefore, the ease of modification of COFs presents a promising opportunity for the coupling of COF-based single-site photocatalysts with other semiconductors. This coupling enhances charge separation and transportation, mass transport, and electron conductivity. Thus, superior photocatalytic and electrocatalytic activities are desired. 8 Summary and perspective In summary, the pre-designable, structurally diverse, and well-ordered nanochannel advantages of crystalline COFs endow them with great potential as ideal candidate materials for establishing COF-based single-site catalysts for photocatalysis and electrocatalysis. Various types of species, such as single metal ions, single atoms, single active sites, and metal clusters, which serve as capture centers for electrons or active sites, can be coupled with target COFs using different synthetic approaches, including in-situ photo-deposition, post-impregnation, and directed assembly. Consequently, COF-based single-site materials have garnered significant attention and exhibit promising applications in solar energy and electricity conversion owing to their enriched active sites and the synergistic effects of single sites and COFs. This review comprehensively summarizes the structural basis, synthesis, and recent advances in the fields of photo- and electrocatalysis using COF-based single-site catalysts. Among them, COF-based single-site catalysts, owing to the encapsulated active sites and the photoresponsivity of COFs, have been extensively employed in photocatalytic CO2 reduction, water splitting, H2O2 production, N2 fixation, contaminant degradation, and organic transformation, and electrocatalytic H2 evolution, CO2 reduction, O2 reduction, O2 evolution, and N2 fixation. Theoretical calculations are useful for elucidating the pathways of COF-based single-site catalysts. This review shows that although great endeavors for COF-based single-site catalysts have been made and achieved in photo- and electrocatalysis, further investigation of the catalytic mechanism and improvement of activity, stability, and production selectivity to meet practical needs remain desired. As a result, challenges related to N2 fixation and CH4 oxidation persist, indicating that the photo- and electrocatalytic applications of COF-based single-site catalysts are still at an early stage. Significant developmental opportunities and challenges exist for further in-depth research. (1) Suitable and functional COFs materials, regarded as substrates, should be rationally chosen to anchor a single metal atom and optimize the strength of the metal-support interaction. The construction of COF-based hybrids with electrically conductive materials, such as CNTs, GO, and carbon quantum dots, is an effective means of enhancing the conductivity of COFs for electrocatalysis. The utilization of artificial intelligence offers an effective approach for designing highly efficient COF-based single-site catalysts. (2) In addition to using typical characterization approaches, such as HAADF-STEM and EXAFS spectroscopy, to identify the coordination environment of COF-based single-atom photocatalysts, more advanced characterizations, such as the in-situ methods, should also be explored to further clarify the distinction between the different single-atom coordination environments and evaluate the key reaction intermediates by proposing concrete photocatalytic reaction pathways. Moreover, accurate identification of the active sites and understanding their dynamic catalysis in catalysts is a critical and challenging task that can to be achieved using in-situ technologies. (3) Investigating the structural and functional cooperation between COFs and a single-site is necessary for photo-electrocatalytic and electrocatalytic applications. The specific mechanism can also be investigated by in-situ tests and theoretical calculations, which are important tools for clarifying the electron transfer properties and local coordination structure over COF-based single-site photo- and electrocatalysts. The confinement effects of the COF pores on the interactions between single-sites and reactants should be considered, as it could affect the selectivity of the catalytic products. (4) Currently, there is a lack of comprehensive understanding regarding the mechanisms underlying overall water splitting and CO2 reduction over COF-based single-site catalysts. The exploration of COF-based single-site catalysts for N2 fixation and CH4 activation is still in its early stages; thus, it is critical to further explore and expand the applications of N2 fixation and CH4 activation. In addition, it is important to consider the selectivity of the products and fully leverage the advantages of COFs possible. In general, COF-based single-site catalysts have great development potential in photo- and electrocatalytic applications and are expected to achieve excellent catalytic performance. Future research should integrate experimental and theoretical calculation studies to gain a comprehensive understanding of the preparation and reaction mechanisms, for the development of COF-based single-site photo-and electrocatalysts. We believe that this comprehensive review provides a useful guide for designing COF-based single-site catalysts. References 1 S. Chu Y. Cui N. Liu Nat. Mater. 16 2017 16 22 S. Chu, Y. Cui, N. Wu, G. Liu, J. He, C. Yu, G. Zeng, J. Mater. Chem. A, 2022, 10, 228–233. Liuyi Li is currently a professor at College of Materials Science and Engineering, Fuzhou University, China. He received his Master and Doctor degrees in 2007 from Huazhong University of Science and Technology and in 2017 from Fuzhou University. He was a associate researcher in Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2009−2017. His current research interests focus on rational design of covalent organic frameworks for photocatalysis, especially for photocatalytic CO2 reduction and water splitting. He has published more than 50 peer-reviewed papers. Yan Yu is a professor in Fuzhou University. She is the Director- general of the Fujian Ceramic Society. She received her B.Sc., M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees from Fuzhou University. She was a postdoctoral fellow in Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences and became a full professor at Fuzhou University in 2011. Her research interest includes environmental remediation, water purification, ecological materials, photocatalysis, electrocatalysis. She has published more than 220 papers. Shenghong Zhong (College of Materials Science and Engineering, Fuzhou University) received his B.Sc. degree (2011) in Chemistry from University of Science and Technology of China (USTC), and Ph.D. degree (2019) in materials science and engineering from King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST). Since the end of 2019, he has been working in Fuzhou University as an associate professor. His research interests mainly focus on non-precious metal nanomaterials, electrocatalysis, aqueous zinc batteries, and liquid metals. He has published more than 20 peer-reviewed papers.

coredata.dc:description: Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) represent a burgeoning category of highly tunable crystalline porous materials, which have garnered significant attention as promising platforms for designing novel photo- and electrocatalysts. Single-site catalysis holds paramount importance in revealing the catalytic reaction mechanism and enhancing catalytic performance because of the maximum utilization of metal atoms and presence of a definite active center. Given the distinct advantages of single-site catalysts, such as single metal ions, single atoms, single active sites, and metal clusters, and COFs materials, there is a current surge of interest in using COFs materials as support materials to anchor highly dispersed single-sites. Consequently, the design and preparation of COF-based single-site catalysts have emerged as a prominent research topic in the fields of photo- and electrocatalysis, to address the pressing environmental and energy issues. This review provides an overview of the development of COF-based single-site photo- and electrocatalysts. Advanced applications of COF-based single-site photo- and electrocatalysts are comprehensively summarized and reviewed. Additionally, the review addresses the challenges faced by COF-based single-site photo- and electrocatalysts and discusses their future development trends. We aim to provide new insights into the application of COF-based single-site materials in photo- and electrocatalysis and further promote the development of catalytic science.
